Of this amount, $1.4 billion was intended to provide 1980s protection ‚Äì like the Comite project ‚Äì while the $1.2 billion was designed for projects like LA 22 that are regional and collaborative in nature and address future protection and the risks revealed by the 2016 Flood.

When we secured $3 billion in 2018 for flood projects, the LA 22 project is precisely what we had in mind: a strategic investment in systemic, watershed-based flood protection as opposed to sprinkling money around on isolated projects.

The LA 22 project is the first major flood project since the historic 2016 Flood ‚Äì and the first regional project in the Capital Region since the Comite River Diversion Canal was proposed more than 30 years ago.
